Administration today signed the international agreement to fight global warming, affirming a crucial American role in a long environmental crusade but not raising any hope of Senate approval in the near future.

The sig

which the Administration has long promised, reinforces its commitment to the treaty, which calls for sharp cuts in emissions of industrial gases from burning coal, oil, wood and natural gas. But the accord is not legall

binding unless the Senate approves it.

Vice President Al Gore said, "Our signing of the protocol underscores our determination to achieve a truly global solution to this global challenge." But he emphasized that much m

bargaining lies ahead.

Treaty opponents in the United States immediately raised an outcry, but the step was widely applauded in Buenos Aires, where 150 nations are debating how the treaty can be put into effect.

Stuar

E. Eizenstat, the chief American delegate to the talks there, announced this morning that the United States would sign the pact, which was negotiated last year in Kyoto, Japan. A. Peter Burleigh, the acting American rep

to the United Nations, signed it in New York this afternoon.

But the Administration, as expected, will not yet submit the Kyoto Protocol for approval by the Senate, where it faces substantial opposition from critics wh

say the costs to industry would damage the economy.

The White House has said all along that the United States would sign it before the deadline next March, but would not ratify it unless key American provisos are accep

Given the pace of the continuing talks, that probably means not before the elections in 2000.

The protocol strengthens a global treaty negotiated in Rio de Janiero in 1992 and ratified during the Bush Administration. M

scientists say rising concentrations of greenhouse gases, warming the earth's surface like an invisible quilt, are threatening grave environmental harm.

Without the participation of the United States, the leading sourc

of waste industrial gases, the agreement would collapse. The United States was the 60th nation to sign.

"Kyoto is a landmark achievement but it is a work in progress and key issues remain outstanding," said Mr. Eizenst

who is the Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs. 

In a telephone interview, he said the signing was intended to strengthen Washington's negotiating hand. But critics in Congress, echoing the views of their cons

in industries like coal and automobiles, said it would reduce American leverage.

Mr. Eizenstat called the announcement a high point in negotiations that otherwise have focused on small advances toward putting the compl

agreement into force.

"I am not gilding the lily when I say there was near euphoria among delegates here," he said. "They just felt this was a real sign of U.S. leadership. I think there was really a doubt that we were

y going to pursue this, with all the opposition in the Senate and in other quarters. The feeling was that perhaps the domestic opposition was so stiff that we were going to back off."

To fulfill the accord, the United S

would have to cut its emissions by about 7 percent from the 1990 level over the next 10 to 15 years. Emissions have been steadily increasing since 1990, making that target very ambitious.

The conditions that the United

s is demanding are meant to hold down the costs of compliance and to increase the chance that the Senate will eventually approve.

One condition is a system of trading "emissions credits," effectively allowing the United

s to reduce its own emissions less by paying other countries to reduce theirs more. Another is persuading developing nations to take a larger role in cutting emissions, encouraging them with financial assistance from dev

nations, which would get emissions credits in exchange.

Both ideas face strong resistance from some countries that say the first steps must be taken by industrial nations like the United States, which emits about a qua

of all greenhouse gases.

Opponents of the treaty are marshalling opposition in Congress, arguing that the targets cannot be met without damaging the economy.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat and a l

treaty proponent, said in Buenos Aires that signing the protocol "gives us the credibility to be at the table" in the continuing talks. "That means we can not only make sure it happens, but that it happens in the way th

we prefer," he said.

But a Democrat who opposes the protocol, Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, said, "The timing of this signing only encourages countries who refuse to be part of any effort to limit emissio

On Wednesday Argentina pledged to curb its emissions, and today Kazakhstan also did so, but populous countries like China and India, whose emissions are growing fast, resist formal limits.

"The President has chosen a

path both domestically and internationally," said Connie Holms, the chairwoman of the Global Climate Coalition, which represents major industry groups opposed to the treaty. "Clinton has sent the U.S. careening down an

highway which appears on no maps, has no speed limits, no police patrols, and no exit or entrance ramps."

Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, who sponsored a Senate resolution last year that opposed signing th

treaty unless certain conditions were met, said the signing "blatantly contradicts the will of the United States Senate" and dared President Clinton to submit it to the Senate, where a two-thirds vote is required for ap

"If this treaty is good enough to sign, it's good enough to be submitted to the Senate for an open, honest debate," he said.

Environmental groups praised the signing, but some complained that the United States is not

enough yet to reduce greenhouse gas.

"Without a more vigorous commitment to domestic action, U.S. demands for more action by developing countries are like a chain-smoking parent telling his children that smoking is bad

for them," said John Adams, president of the 

Natural Resources Defense Council. He urged the Administration to take unilateral steps to cut emissions of carbon dioxide from automobiles, power plants and other sources.

SIX years ago, Peter Leske (then with the Australian Wine Research Institute, now winemaker for Nepenthe Wines) and I went to Portugal to evaluate the cork industry. Before we left Australia, we had made it clear to th

Portuguese trade office (our host) that we doubted whether we would find much to be positive about, and we would report on what we found, good or bad.

 We came away disillusioned, and published articles highly critical

f the practices and attitude of the cork producers and their associations to the issue of cork taint. As hosts, they were invariably courteous and generous, their country a joy. But we were not there on one of the touris

junkets that had been organised for larger groups of journalists.

In May, I returned as the guest of Amorim and Irmaos SA, the largest of the cork producers. Each year it sells 3.1 billion to 3.2 billion corks, account

for 25 per cent to 30 per cent of the cork stopper industry. (It also produces other cork products, chiefly from the cork waste of the stopper industry or lesser-grade cork.)

 Before I left Australia, I was aware of a

change in attitude. Instead of the state of absolute, bare-faced denial of 1995, Amorim (and most other leading producers) had publicly stated the eradication of cork taint is of paramount importance, and outlined far-r

changes in production techniques directed to this end.

 But many doubts remained, many questions needed to be answered. What percentage of corks was being produced by the new techniques? How long would it take to move

the experimental stage to full-scale commercial application? What guarantees could be given about the effectiveness of the new techniques in reducing the incidence of the main cork-taint, trichloranisole (universally ab

to TCA)?

 Well, Amorim is deadly serious in its approach. It built a new manufacturing plant at Ponte Sur in March last year and a second will be completed at Coruche later this year. Both are in Alentajo, the principa

region for cork trees, and each cost $18 million to build and equip. More than 10ha of buildings and open cement or tarmac storage areas at each factory will produce 80 per cent of Amorim's corks. The remaining 20 per c

will be produced under contract by smaller companies, and sold and distributed by a separate company into markets more concerned with price than quality -- certainly not to Australia.

 Research continues at the fastest

e rate, development of new techniques likewise. But Antonio Amorim, chief executive of the cork division, knows that the clock is ticking remorselessly. Unless the cork industry -- or, more particularly, Amorim -- can re

the position where it can provide a fault-free product, alternative closures (synthetic corks, Stelvin screw caps or something entirely new) will slowly but surely take market share away from natural cork.

 There is not a shred of self-deception on this: Antonio Amorim is an intelligent and astute man. Australia is the most demanding and critical market (and one of rapidly growing imp

and, if Amorim can satisfy its requirements, the other markets with fall into line.

 The process of cork handling and manufacture has been changed: contact between the stripped bark and earth has been eliminated; the b

of the trunk bark is cut off and used elsewhere (cork tiles, gaskets and the like); a radically new boiling process in the equivalent of a giant surgical autoclave is used, as are ozone chambers; numerous gas chromatogr

mass spectrometry machines to identify TCA in corks have been installed; there's a patented INOS II system to extract TCA from the discs used in sparkling wine corks; and twin-top corks have been developed using champag

cork technology.

 Research in the US, Australia and Portugal into a recently discovered ability of finished corks to absorb TCA from solution may prove to be of critical importance. So may work with alternative forms o

glue for use with sparkling wine and twin-top corks. It may not yet be time to start counting chickens, but the hens are certainly laying.

HALLIDAY'S CHOICE

It is bad enough when the New Zealander

flood the market with sauvignon blanc, but it's worse when they produce semillon which, as everyone knows, tastes rank and vegetal in New Zealand, to the far right of even sauvignon blanc. But there are always exception

to the rule, and in 1999 and, now again in 2000, the Montana Gisborne Semillon ($14.95, 88 points) is a pretty nifty wine. Herb, grass, nettle, and mineral aromas foreshadow a crisp, clean, nicely balanced palate, with

15 per cent of the wine having been barrel-fermented and matured in oak for four months. The rest is stainless steel-fermented and stored, the barrel ferment component adding to the texture rather than the flavour. Montana says serve it with a salad of goat's cheese and rocket leaves, and I wouldn't argue with that.

years of free publicity for piles of manure and recently orphaned goats, the options for ethical gift giving remain fairly limited. But there's nothing to stop discerning consumers from devising their own ethical gifts

this time of year. Here are a few suggestions.

A decent Italian restaurant: The problem with the developing world is not poverty, corruption or the fact that Angelina Jolie is taking all its children. It's that there a

no decent Italian joints to have a meal at. For just $875, you can build a new restaurant in Gabon and train the chefs in how to assemble a passable beef carpaccio.

A toy poodle: Pigs, cows, sheep, chicken - doubtless,

e animals all have their uses. But when you're strutting down the main avenue in Kinshasa with your new Chanel tote bag hanging from your arm and wearing a sexy little black Armani number, what use is a pig to you? You d

need a pig at this point - you need a miniature dog. This is the problem with much of the trend towards "ethical gift-giving" - the poor in the world's developing nations might benefit, but the extremely wealthy are inv

left with nothing. This betrays the very principle of equity in whose name the whole trend has been initiated. It is also unwise in a practical sense. As the old saying reminds us: "Send an African peasant a goat, and y

will have a friend for life. Send the wife of a corrupt African politician a toy poodle, and if you're ever in her country, you will have somewhere safe to stay when the Islamic insurgents attack and all flights out of

place are suspended."

A scungy white T-shirt: The problem with so many of the world's people is that even though they eke out an existence of relentlessly grinding misery tilling an overworked earth for whatever meagre

s her scarred and threadbare surface may yet yield, they don't have the clothes to prove it. To look at most of the world's farmers from developing countries today, you'd think they'd just stepped out of the all-you-can-

buffet at Sizzler with a doggy bag and the latest Judd Apatow DVD tucked under their arm. They're not dressed for poverty. To remedy this PR disaster, why not consider giving the gift of one of your crappy old white T-s

Add a pair of discarded Reebok pumps and some stonewash jeans, and before you know it, your unruly cohort of Mauritanian camel herders will be moving into a warehouse studio in Erskineville to "cut an EP".

Free gym mem

bership: Is it any wonder the people of the developing world are so out of shape, when so many of them struggle to scratch up the cash for a gym membership? Get the kids of the sub-Saharan belt into pump class, and we need never be troubled by Bob Geldof again.

Dec. 5 -- In a clear signal that active diplomacy is at work to forge an agreement in Paris based on voluntary pledges, one that is subject to transparent monitoring, India said on Friday that it was ready for a regime

stocktaking of future carbon emissions. The U.S., on its part, said it had "nothing but respect" for India's approach at the climate talks.

 "We are comfortable and welcome the process, even at a five-yearly cycle," sa

Susheel Kumar, Additional Secretary in the Environment Ministry, adding "What we are trying to convey is that the process should be linked to the next cycle, not the present one." India's first Intended Nationally Deter

Contributions (INDCs) are for the 2021-2030 period, and it would prefer a review after that.

 However, India is not in a position to fix a target year for peaking of carbon emissions because of the current state of its

. The Centre had engaged several technical institutions to do modelling studies, but they could not identify a likely peaking date due to uncertainty. Neither was it possible to predict what percentage of nuclear power w

form part of renewable energy due to several hurdles, although the target was to generate 63 GW by 2032.

 The Indian side got an endorsement from the U.S. Special Envoy for Climate Change, Todd Stern. "I have had four

five meetings with Indian counterparts in just the last week, and we are working quite intensively and in a businesslike and constructive way. I have nothing but respect for the Indians," he said. The U.S. talks with In

follow President Barack Obama's meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday. "[It was] an extraordinarily rich exchange, very substantive, the two leaders have a tremendous rapport. The President is very substan

tuned into this issue, and wanted to talk substance and did. PM Modi was every bit ready to do the same and so it was very good conversation," the U.S. envoy told the media.

 The U.S., which did not ratify the Kyoto Pr

that fixed quantified emissions reductions, would like to have a transparency regime in the Paris agreement that would build trust. Transparency would allow everybody to have confidence and trust that others were acting

o reduce carbon. There would be a role for other countries in the process and also civil society, the press and think tanks. Countries should be encouraged to do the best that they can, but not expected to do more than t

can, Mr. Stern said.

 However, it remains firm on the issue of historic responsibility. It is unwilling to concede that it had emitted the greenhouse gases now concentrated in the atmosphere in large measure. It will n

therefore accept that there should be liability and compensation for loss and damage. "This is not a U.S.-centric position but virtually [of] all developed countries," Mr. Stern said on the question of including provisi

for loss and damage in the Paris text. 

Cooperative and constructive discussions were on with both islands and G77 on developing a solution, besides the EU.

 The draft Paris agreement, of which a new iteration with fe

pages was released on Friday, has controversial optional text which says all parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change who were "in a position to do so" should provide assistance to developing countries i

the area of finance, for mitigation and adaptation.

 To questions on what this meant, Mr. Stern said historically, the developed countries had been donors and they would continue to provide. But already "developing cou

have contributed to the Green Climate Fund." China had made an announcement of $3 billion dollars for a south-south fund for climate assistance. Contribution was voluntary, and if some countries over-read it as some new

, "it is not," he said. Progress after week-1

 Defending the Obama administration's handling of the climate change issue, he said it had taken extraordinary measures using existing clean energy and environment laws to c

emissions. There would always be challenges from Congress and people who did not like to see EPA regulate, but the agency had a very strong record of prevailing.

 On Thursday night, India joined China and the Arab grou

led by Saudi Arabia in calling for exclusion of substantive recommendations on keeping global temperature rise to below 1.5 degrees C made by a review panel under the Structured Expert Dialogue system of UNFCCC, in the

to the CoP21 negotiating parties.

 While the Arab group led by Saudi Arabia "blocked" the proposal, India and China were "less adamant and more diplomatic". But they went along with Saudi position since there was no ag

on how the review report coming after three years of work should be handled, civil society organisations said.

In summary, the review favoured a 1.5 degrees rise over a 2 degree rise that would greatly affect vulnerabl

nations, said Climate Action Network International, a collective of 850 NGOs society organisations.

 Civil society organisations also felt that there was greater progress in Paris at the end of one week than there had

at Copenhagen in 2009, Kelly Dent, Food, Climate and Humanitarian Advocacy Manager at Oxfam Australia said. Greenpeace, the NGO which has had a troubled relationship with the NDA government, today urged Prime Minister N

Modi to play a heroic role at CoP21, and pledge a total shift to renewable energy in India by 2050.

 The Executive Director of Greenpeace International Kumi Naidoo expressed the NGOs sympathy with those suffering from

in Chennai, and said those who had to respond to it faced great challenges. Climate change was not made by India, but the country was paying the price.

 Major polluters should be held accountable for historical greenho

use gas emissions that had produced climate change. A shift to total renewable energy access by 2050 was the only way to keep a rise in global temperature under 1.5 degrees C, which was essential to save the most vulnerable countries. A complete shift to renewable energy would produce millions of clean energy jobs.

Gaza Strip - For eight days, the sounds of illegal commerce here at the ragged southern edge of the Gaza Strip were silenced by the pounding thrum of battle.

Israeli military jets bombed the sandy stretch of land just

center fielder's throw from Egypt each day, hoping to collapse the underground avenues for food, cars, medicines and weapons that support Hamas's rule in Gaza.

Ahmad al-Arja, a 22-year-old engineering student, was amon

the army of diggers forced to take the conflict off. But minutes after Israel and Hamas reached a cease-fire on the evening of Nov. 21, his boss was on the phone.

"He said, 'Come on, count on God, and tomorrow morning,

t digging,'â€Š" Arja recalled, as he began with his cousins the tedious, treacherous work of tunnel repair.

The business of Rafah is the tunnel network that circumvents the Israeli blockade of Gaza, and business once ag

is booming.

For Israeli leaders, who are seeking assurances since the recent cease-fire that Hamas be prevented from restocking its potent weapons arsenal, the thriving return of tunnel commerce poses a daunting strate

challenge.

Since leaving Gaza seven years ago, Israel's military has lost its on-the-ground ability to stop tunnel smuggling. Since the cease-fire, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has sought guarantees from E

President Mohamed Morsi that he will do more to prevent the illegal trade into Gaza - a diplomatic negotiation between uneasy neighbors that in the past has proved fruitless.

Without such help, the trade will almost ce

continue. As Israel has found in trying to suppress rocket fire from Gaza, an airstrike campaign against the tunnels provides a respite, not a solution. 

"Our expectation of Egypt, and the rest of the international com

is to stop Hamas from rearming," said Mark Regev, a spokesman for Netanyahu. "We believe they came out of this latest round significantly depleted in terms of rockets and missiles. The way to prevent a future round is t

prevent their ability to rearm."

Maj. Avital Leibovitz, an Israel Defense Forces spokesman, said there is so far no evidence any new arms shipments have gone through the tunnels since the cease-fire.

Leibovitz said an

i ground presence is not necessary to stop smuggling under the border. Like the intelligence assets that the military drew on to target underground rocket launchers, she said, "we know what we need to know" about the tun

Whether that will always be enough is unclear.

Israel targeted 140 tunnels during the recent operation, severely damaging dozens of passages beneath Gaza's nearly seven-mile border with the Egyptian Sinai. The bombs b

entrances, destroyed concrete-reinforced walls and cratered the muddy access roads used by flatbed trucks that deliver goods across the strip.

Hamas security officials who monitor the tunnels - and collect "taxes" from

e merchants who buy the imports - say at least 50 were collapsed along one busy mile-long stretch alone. Diggers think that hundreds of tunnels span the border.

But as the Arja family and others toiling under a warm win

sun less than a week after the cease-fire made clear, none of the tunnels will remain dormant for long.

"Some wanted to get to work during the bombings," said Mohammed Bahrawi, 23, a Hamas guard who monitors a particul

busy patch of tunnels. "But, look, they were crazy. We wouldn't let them."

Dressed in an all-black military uniform, Bahrawi walked among the churned, pitted landscape that hummed with generators, bulldozers and trucks

The trucks hauled smuggled propane gas canisters, crates of fish and gravel into the strip for sale.

Only three months ago, Bahrawi was a digger himself. A business administration graduate of Khan Younis College of Sci

and Technology, Bahrawi, like many young Gazans, could not find work in his field. So he turned to the tunnels.

Hamas officials chose him three months ago to help guard the site, which they monitor constantly.

Bahrawi

d it is his job to make sure only permitted goods come through the tunnels, and to prevent people from using them to leave for Egypt.

"But I am not going to lie to you," Bahrawi said. "Many other things enter, too."

Of

y concern to Israel are the weapons - missiles, small arms and explosives - that military officials say have arrived in Gaza from Iran, Sudan and Libya through the tunnels.

Bahrawi points toward clusters of apartment bu

their walls pocked long ago by Israeli shrapnel. Many of the tunnels, he said, have secret extensions that end out of sight. Those are the ones used to smuggle materials that Israel is not meant to see.

The tunnels var

in size and depth. Two that are big enough for cars to enter stand on either end of a roughly mile- long stretch - one damaged by the bombing is closed, the other is open for business.

The most common are spacious enou

for men to stand in with room to spare, and wide enough for large crates to pass through. In one dusty shaft, a makeshift elevator carried men up and down. 

But the sandy soil above the diggers has shifted during the r

bombardment, and Bahrawi thinks collapses are inevitable as they attempt to reopen the passages.

"Some have been working in these tunnels for seven years, and I think once you see some of these men hit the right depth

start to head toward Egypt, there will be deaths," he said.

The men, who earn about $15 a day, sweat in the sun. Small fires smoke from several of the pits, used to heat kettles of water for morning tea.

Down in the v

entry shafts, diggers pause for a cigarette, buckets of wet cement at their feet. Over the din of generators and excavation equipment, a man's yell from time to time signals dray horses to haul large bags of damp soil u

from the pits.

"They will bomb again," Arja said. "And then we will dig again - and there will be more money."

To Abu Ahmed, a tunnel owner who gave only his nickname, the frantic restoration underway brings a smile.

A former digger who saved enough to make his own tunnel, Abu Ahmed said he lost about $8,000 during the tunnel closures caused by Israel's airstrikes.

On a recent morning, his workers dragged stacks of Styrofoam crates

with Egyptian sardines through his undamaged tunnel. He sells each crate for about $50, and every merchant who places an order pays 14.5 percent of the price to the Hamas officials on site. The money goes into the movem

ent's treasury.

That is only one expense. Recently, a worker died and five others were injured in an accident inside Abu Ahmed's tunnel. A Hamas-led committee fixed the amount of restitution that he paid to the men's families, which came to a total of about $30,000.

"It's always worrying, but what else can I do? This is our business," he said. "You cannot imagine the effort we put into these tunnels."

Inheritance: Book One. By Christopher Paolini. 509 pp. New York: Alfred A Knopf. $18.95. (Ages 10 and up)

 WITH all the hoopla surrounding the publication of "Eragon" and its 19-year-old author, Christopher Paolini, it

t easy to read this first novel "plain" -- that is, without preconceptions. The young author, who has been home- schooled, began writing a planned trilogy at 15, published the first edition himself with the help of his f

then sold it to Alfred A. Knopf for a large advance -- it's a real Cinderella story, one that makes J. K. Rowling's experience with Harry Potter appear modest. Nonetheless, there is the work itself, a 509-page fantasy,

what is one to make of it?

"Eragon" is about an ordinary boy -- he's 15 at the start of this book, 16 by the end -- who finds a strange blue stone in a stretch of mountains known as the Spine. "Nature had never polishe

a stone as smooth as this one. Its flawless surface was dark blue, except for thin veins of white that spiderwebbed across it. The stone was cool and frictionless under his fingers, like hardened silk."

Eragon has all

makings of a classic literary hero -- he is poor, orphaned, brave and impulsive. His history is mysterious even to him; he scrapes out a meager living working with his taciturn uncle and a cousin -- and his life is swif

overturned when the blue stone hatches a dragon, commencing a journey into murder and magic, among elves, warriors, kings and monsters, leading, of course, to a battle between good and evil. It is a familiar plot, but o

has never been one of the fantasy genre's strengths.

By its nature, fantasy draws upon archetypes -- less enchanted readers might call them stereotypes -- of heroes and villains, magic and magical creatures. Some write

like Ursula K. Le Guin and Anne McCaffrey, use exquisite prose. Others, like J. R. R. Tolkien and J. K.Rowling, create reverberating plots that twist and dive with a dramatic flexibility that is like swordsmanship or da

Paolini does not yet have these strengths. He often slips into cliched descriptions -- "His tanned skin rippled with lean muscles" -- or

B-movie dialogue: " 'Boy!' roared Brom. 'You demand answers with an insolence ra

seen.' " His prose can be awkward and gangly: "Things that had been permanent and unquestionable were suddenly thrown into doubt. 

Eventually he had learned to live with it, but he always had a nagging suspicion that h

had not been good enough for his mother. I'm sure there was a good reason for what she did; I only wish I knew what it was."

The plot stumbles and jerks along, with gaps in logic and characters dropped, then suddenly r

or new ones invented at the last minute. And yet, as Beatrix Potter wrote, "Genius -- like murder -- will out." "Eragon," for all its flaws, is an authentic work of great talent. The story is gripping; it may move awkwa

but it moves with force. The power of "Eragon" lies in its overall effects -- in the sweep of the story and the conviction of its storyteller. Here, Paolini is leagues ahead of most writers, and it is exactly here that

youth is on his side.

Some of our greatest writers have written badly, at least some of the time, from Tolstoy to Dreiser to Crane. Paolini has a passionate commitment to his story, and he has created some fine images.

s room is cold and bare, but "covered with objects he had collected. There were twisted pieces of wood, odd bits of shells, rocks that had broken to reveal shiny interiors, and strips of dry grass tied into knots. His fa

item was a root so convoluted he never tired of looking at it."

The hatching of the dragon's egg is a lovely scene, and more wonderful is the fledgling dragon herself: "When dawn came, the dragon was sitting atop his b

like an ancient sentinel welcoming the new day. Eragon marveled at its color. He had never seen such a clear, hard blue."

But this is fundamentally a gloomy book.

Eragon, a true teenage hero, is moody, angry and sombe

questioning the meaning of life. "Love, family, accomplishments -- they are all torn away, leaving nothing. What is the worth of anything we do?" He punches things a lot, and spends most of the time injured or bruised.

it's impossible not to become attached to him and care about his fate. Paolini never dwells on evil, though its presence haunts the novel. But unlike the vast majority of contemporary writers, he keeps most blood and go

offstage; brutality is something to mourn, to resist.

There are marvelous surprises, as in the first contact between Eragon and his dragon, or their first flight together: "She crouched and her wings rushed upward. The

hung there for an instant, then drove down as she flung herself into the sky. Eragon yelled as the ground dropped away and they rose above the trees. Turbulence buffeted him, snatching the breath out of his mouth."

The truth is, standards set by governments for protection of the environment and vehicle occu

are more important to carmakers when designing new models than any considerations of appearance.

If you think most passenger cars on the market are growing closer in appearance and their inbuilt safety features, you're

. The first thing a new vehicle has to do is to meet legislated requirements. Only then can it be styled to gain maximum popular appeal.

Mandatory levels of fuel economy are becoming common in many countries. As fuel ec

is largely a function of weight, this means designing every component to weigh as little as possible.

Body shapes are critical to reducing fuel-consuming drag. The shapes of modern vehicles reflect the need to be aerod

"slippery", which means they're growing increasingly similar in appearance.

Safety, particularly with regards to protection of occupants from injury in case of an accident, means that air bags and side intrusion bars a

incorporated into almost every new vehicle designed. The inclusion of airbags and side intrusion bars also has a bearing on the styling - and cost - of the finished product.

FISITA, an international body that represent

27 national engineering organisations and their 130,000 engineer members, recently held their biannual conference in Prague.

They issued a statement warning that differing environmental and "safety" standards could soo

account for 10 to 15 per cent of the total cost of a vehicle unless regulators and politicians could accept the "automotive facts of life".

FISITA's outgoing President, Jack Schmidt, who is a former director of power t

for General Motors, said the association is seeking a global harmonisation of standards.

"We do promote safety and a better environment", he said, noting that FISITA's role was to provide a forum that will gather toget

members of the political and technical communities as well as the public.

He rightly pointed out that automotive engineers have the responsibility for providing the technical solutions in matters of safety, emissions a

even ways of recycling vehicle components.

The underlying theme is that a universal set of vehicle standards covering such areas as emissions, passenger safety and fuel consumption would enable automotive engineers wor

to apply their expertise to developing the best ways of meeting these standards. 

There are profits to be made by coming up with ways to meet legislated standards, as demonstrated by Australia's growing automotive comp

industry. It earns a steadily increasing income from exports of components, engines and engine parts, estimated at $1.1 billion in 1995.

Developments like the orbital engine with its lightweight construction are critic

al to achieving vehicle weight targets.

BHP Steel is working on lightweight steel body technology that will enable carmakers to combine lower body weight with increased occupant safety.

Our future transport will also be far less polluting and cheaper to run and service than our present generation of cars.

The people who will make all this possible are the automotive engineers.

Delhi, Dec 14 -- Kerala's first forest soil museum, established by the Kerala Forest Research Institute (KFRI) at its campus in Peechi, highlights the diversity of forest soil and mineral resources in the State and prov

critical inputs for forest management.

 The main attraction of the museum is a collection of 15 soil monoliths featuring the soils in different types of forests including shola, evergreen, and semievergreen, grasslands

plantations, and degraded forests in Kerala. A monolith is essentially a profile representing the soil typical of a region, with all the basic characteristics preserved intact. "The forest soil museum is the first of it

kind in India and provides valuable information on soil genesis and transformation in the humid tropics," says M.P. Sujatha, head, department of soil sciences, KFRI. "Forest ecosystems make strong imprints on the soil b

them. They are signatures of the vegetation, climate, rainfall, topography, and rocks in a particular region." 15 soil monoliths

 The museum has a set of 15 soil monoliths, which preserve and display the vertical secti

of the soil from the surface to the bedrock below displaying the various horizontal layers or genetic horizons. Each monolith was dug from the ground and processed for more than a month before being mounted for display.

e each monolith is information about the soil, including the physical and chemical characteristics of the soil, the forest type and significant features. Other exhibits include a geologic mapof Kerala, a map showing the

ecological zones and units represented in the State and collections of rocks and minerals. "Any degradation of a forest ecosystem is reflected in the soil profile," says S. Sandeep, scientist, KFRI. "By obviating the ne

ed to scan an entire forest to assess the extent of degradation, it can be a valuable tool in forest management and conservation." Suresh Das, executive vice president, Kerala State Council for Science, Technology and Environment inaugurated the museum on Thursday at the opening session of a national seminar on soil health hosted by KFRI.
